newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila bank needs partner to boost capital base.
newsitem.headline: Manila bank needs partner to boost capital base.

text.p: Formerly state-owned Philippine National Bank needs a stable partner to further build up its capital base and make it less vulnerable to speculative attacks in the stock market, bank officials said.
Fifty-seven percent of PNB's equity is now owned by about 25,000 private shareholders while the government, with a 43 percent equity control, remains the biggest single stockholder.
PNB president Peter Favila told reporters on Saturday the wide ownership base made it difficult for the newly privatised bank to sanction a capital increase.
At the same time, he said, PNB cannot expect capital infusion from the government as this would be inconsistent with its privatisation policy.

PNB stocks dipped to 287 pesos per share from 307 pesos last Thursday on rumours Favila had resigned due to failing health but it rebounded to 310 pesos the next day after the reports proved baseless.
Favila said the bank's wide ownership base made the stock vulnerable to speculation, hence the need for a tie-up with a partner to make its ownership base more stable.
